question: I don't know. And if you ask me again, I'm going to slug you. It's been fun, hasn't it, kids? You're welcome! Damnit, Bill, you know I need to check it first! Better than turpentine. Tastes about the same. Your call, Bill. You ain't picky, Bill. I like that about you. 'Running on Empty'? Tell me about it. Hey, Bill! We got TV! 147 channels. Everything from Jesus to 'Jeopardy'. 'Like sands through the hour- glass, so are the days of our lives...' 'Michael Shields, come on down, you're the next contestant on...'The Price is Right'.' I'll take Domestic Nuclear Disasters for two hundred thousand, Alex... We interrupt our regularly scheduled program to bring you the Second Civil War... Well, shit. I don't want any trouble... I bet you don't either... Let's just call it a draw, okay? Look out, Bill! I'm rich. I'm just passing through. I don't mean anyone any harm. Water's good. I'm not a Holnist. Okay? I'm headed for a town called St. Rose. Somewhere west of Portland.
answer: Portland's under twenty feet of water.

question: Well, I heard different.
answer: You mouthin' me?

question: No, it's just that it's hard to get good information.
answer: Don't be in such a rush, Martin. Now I see a pack mule over there, but I don't see no packs.

question: This is all I got.
answer: Oh... Kill him, Martin.

question: Okay! My stuff's up there!
answer: Shut up. What do you got in there?

question: Dried peas. Beef jerky. Cigarettes. Sure. There's the ladder.
answer: You go up and get it. Just you start tossing those cigarettes down!

question: It's going to take a second. I got my stuff bolted in.
answer: Put some buckshot through it, Martin. Just to hurry him up. So use his gun.

question: What are you doing there? I said, what are you doing?
answer: It's just a game, General Bethlehem. Something they saw in a play. No harm in it.

question: A play? Show me. It's all right, children, show me. Shakespeare, is it? Well, I'm sorry I missed it.
answer: You should know, sir, we haven't nearly stocked the game we thought we would.

question: Really? But you had time for a play? I'm taking three conscripts from each town. They will have the honor of serving in the Holnist Army until such time as I see fit. Three men. You suppose you could do that?
answer: All men between 15 and 50 and of suitable ethnic foundation are required to show themselves now.

question: Acceptable.
answer: Sir?

question: You don't understand...
answer: You were required to show yourself.

question: But, I'm not with these people. I'm just passing through. I --
answer: Take the mule.

question: Hi? Kind of. So what did you guys do with my cigarettes? Wonderful. What happened to your partners?
answer: Welcome, gentlemen, to your new life. You have been born again as soldiers in the army of the United Clans of Holn. The strong have been sapped by the whimpering propaganda of the weak. Men, strong men, have been denied their destiny. You men have been saved from that fate. Redemption is within your grasp. You. What did you do before you were given this opportunity? You digged holes... Well, now you're going to fill them. And you?

question: Me?
answer: Is there any question in anyone's mind that I was talking to you? Yes, you. You look like a dangerous man. Are you?

question: I'm just a performer. Shakespeare. Stuff like that.
answer: Shakespeare?

question: He was a writer. He --
answer: I know who Shakespeare was... 'Cry "Havoc!" and let slip the dogs of war.'

question: I, um, you want a line? 'To be or not to be
answer: 'We few, we happy few, we band of brothers.'

question: 'Now is the winter of our discontent made glorious summer by this son of York.'
answer: You're pretty good. You're also a fighter. I see it in your eyes. Don't you agree? Come on, a man's got to speak his mind.

question: I don't mean any disrespect, sir, but you'd be better off just letting me go. A fighter is about the last thing I am.
answer: Don't you think I should be the judge of that, soldier? Get up. I said, get up. Put up your fists.

question: You'd win.
answer: Now fight. You're right. You're not a fighter. But you will be. I'm giving you a chance at a life that means something. A life worth living.

question: Thanks. Did I win? I tried to tell him...
answer: Say it again.

question: Say what?
answer: The words you said in town. About the wind blowing. And the rest... Say it again.

question: 'Blow, wind. Come wrack. At least we'll die with the harness off our back.'
answer: What's it mean?

question: That's what they're hoping for. These were supposed to be the best years of my life.
answer: The laws of eight, gentlemen. That is the legacy handed down to us by Nathan Holn.

question: May he burn in hell.
answer: These are the laws that we live by. The eight is our symbol. Each man will bear it with pride. Only then will you be part of the clan. Sit down, gentlemen. Law One. You will obey orders without question. I told you to sit. I didn't specify chairs. You could've sat down on the ground. You disobeyed a direct order. You broke Law One. Law Two. Punishment shall be swift. Law Three On your feet! Law Eight

question: As the sword finds its mark. Bethlehem looks at him, but addresses all.
answer: You will get out of this army what you put into it. Work and you'll be fed. Fight and you'll be respected. Die and you'll be remembered. It's up to you.

question: Hey. How ya doin'? 'Jerry Ball, Pine View.' So, arrest me. Here's a piece of good news. Jerry's decided to go to school to get his contractor's license. Little Jimmy wants his grandpa to know he lost a tooth. Thanks for being there for me. Here's to you. I consider my taxes very well spent. All dressed up. Nowhere to go. Well, that's easy. Greetings, Pine View, Oregon! Civilian, I'm on official business. I demand entry into the town of Pine View. I'm through talking to you, buddy boy! Now get somebody with authority to open this gate!
answer: I'm Sheriff Briscoe. Who the hell are you?

question: I'm a representative of the United States Government -- Authorized by order 417 of the restored Congress to reestablish a communication route to Idaho and lower Oregon. Now open that damn gate!
answer: What does that mean in English?

question: I'm your postman!
answer: Hand me your gun.

question: Understand that tampering with or obstructing the mail is a federal offense. Furthermore, the Bolin Act requires you to provide all mail carriers with sanctuary and nourishment. Now open that damn gate!
answer: You got three seconds to get your ass outta here.

question: Is Jerry the contractor here? Wait! I'm going to get something out of my bag.
answer: One!

question: Paul Davis! 124 Vernon Street!
answer: Never heard of him. Two!

question: Lois Kent! 14 Weymoth Lane!
answer: Three!

question: Irene March! 478 River Road!
answer: Did he say my name?

question: Oh, no...
answer: I'm Irene March.

question: I have a letter for you.
answer: Would you read it?

question: I'm sure it's personal.
answer: Please. Someone has to.

question: We're delivering the old stock piles, but I'll accept all new correspondence as well. 'Dear Irene. Sorry I haven't written. Everything's so crazy. The strange weather. The food shortages. That farmer Nathan Holn causing all that trouble. It's hard to understand. David's home from the Army. The war was over before he even got there. Thank God for that. He's still my baby no matter how big he gets. We're going to miss you for Christmas, but maybe next year. All our love. Donna.'
answer: My sister in Denver. Fifteen years ago. Thank you. You're a Godsend. A savior.

question: No. I'm just... a postman. I've been on the road a while. I could use a little something to eat --
answer: Oh, yes, absolutely... Is there anything else?

question: Yes, there is! If there are dogs in this town, you have to leash them while I'm here! 'Stop. Oh, yes, wait a minute, Mr. Postman. Waaa-ait, Mr. Postman...'
answer: Cleaned and pressed, sir.

question: Thanks. Didn't somebody say something about dinner?
answer: Yeah, I'm supposed to take you to Foster's. My name's Ford. Ford Lincoln Mercury. Used to be John Stevens, but I changed it on account of I want to drive cars. I live in that car. A 2003 Pontiac Sinatra. With a nine- banger and a Q-eight.

question: V-eight. Eight cylinders. That means an eight-banger.
answer: Were they fast? A buck seventy-five on a strip. A buck seventy-five? I thought maybe I could fix some of them up. It's nothing compared to what you do.

question: The important thing to remember about cars is, you can't eat 'em. Yeah. You know, I'm pretty hungry. His name is, uh... Richard Starkey. From Maine. He has a saying. 'Things are getting better, getting better all the time.' Parties are over with. The individual is what counts. You vote for the best man. Lady Di's in charge. Sixty years old and she still kicks ass. He died. Skin cancer. The government's just getting started. You're on your own for at least eighteen months. Never thought I'd hear myself say this, but I can't eat anymore. What? This? Almost fits.
answer: Would you like to dance?

question: I don't know if I can, I think I'm still on duty. It's been a long time.
answer: All you got to do is hold on.

question: Is something wrong?
answer: How tall are you?

question: About six feet.
answer: Are you smart?

question: Smarter than some I guess. Why?
answer: Just wondering. Did you ever have the bad mumps?

question: Never had the bad mumps.
answer: Have you ever had herpes or syphilis or anything like that? So as far as you know, you have good semen?

question: Is that a trick question?
answer: I don't mean to be nosy. I'm only asking because I want you to make me pregnant.

question: It's got to be the uniform.
answer: This is my husband. Michael. We've been trying to have a baby for three years. We can't on account of Michael had the bad mumps when he was twelve. So we need a body father. We could ask a man here, but it could cause trouble. I've seen it happen. Things go okay until the woman starts to show. Then it can be bad. But you'll only be around once in awhile with the mail. He hasn't said 'no'.

question: I'll have to think about it.
answer: It's to my daughter Annie. She left five years ago. She was only fifteen. The last I heard, she was living up north...

question: Look, Mrs. March, you should know that...
answer: Know what?

question: Know that...
answer: I have a feeling about you. I know you'll do what's right.

question: I got to get out of here. What is?
answer: I knew you'd come here.

question: You did, huh?
answer: How do you get to be a postman, anyhow?

question: You have to be in the right place at the right time.
answer: How could I do it?

question: I thought you wanted to drive cars.
answer: Not anymore. That was kid's stuff. This is real. So, where's the right place?

question: Could be anywhere. Anytime. Only another postman can make you a postman.
answer: Kinda like vampires, right?

question: Something like that. You have to be sworn in. The organization's kinda shaky. It might not last.
answer: What does?

question: You'd meet a lot of people who don't believe in you.
answer: I'll set them straight.

question: It's a lonely job.
answer: I've been lonely all my life.

question: So have I, Ford. So have I. What the hell? Repeat after me. Okay then.
answer: Okay, then.

question: No, no, no, I'm saying that. You just listen... By my authority you are now empowered to carry the mail. Congratulations, you're a postman.
answer: I want you to know I'd die to get a letter through.

question: Sure thing, Ford.
answer: Johnny's real impressed with you. Whole town's real impressed with you.

question: I take it you're not.
answer: Smarter than you look.

question: What can I do for you, Sheriff?
answer: You can clear out. Or I can throw you out. Either way suits me fine.

question: I'm afraid you don't understand, Sheriff. I'm a government employee. Authorized by --
answer: You're not authorized by shit. You're nothing but a drifter who found a bag of mail. And I want you out of my town.

question: This is going in my report.
answer: These people don't need dreams, Mr. Postman. They need something real. They need help with the goddamn Holnists. Are you going to bring them that? Didn't think so. All you cost us so far is a few bowls of soup and maybe later a few broken hearts. I aim to keep it that way. You can stay till morning. Then I don't ever want to see you again.

question: Just leave it. I said leave it. Hello, Abby.
answer: You'll be leaving tomorrow?

question: I guess.
answer: Everybody's up late writing letters for you to take. We're not supposed to waste candles like that, but they're so excited.

question: How about you? Do you have a letter?
answer: I don't have anybody to write to.

question: I'll find you a pen pal. Someone with interests similar to your own. Dancing, checking for mumps.
answer: You're funny. Hardly anyone's funny around here.

question: I guess no one feels much like laughing.
answer: Have you decided yet?

question: Oh, well, I've been thinking about it. Sure. Why not? God, you're beautiful. Sorry, I know you'd probably like to keep things more clinical. You don't even know my name.
answer: I don't want to. It would be easier for me if you closed your eyes.

question: Okay. They're yours.
answer: I'm your escort out of town.

question: I'll take it. Thank you. Go?... Oh yeah... I'll head west, then work my way back here in a sort of figure eight. Times seem hard right now. But you have to believe it's getting better. Birds are migrating again. The rains are back.
answer: You got a helluva nerve, whoever you are.

question: Is Abby around?
answer: She and Michael are working the north meadow this morning. Well, you're on your own. Hey! Are you really who you say you are?

question: If I come back with some mail, you'll know!
answer: God damn it!

question: Make sure that fire doesn't go out. Good Lord. That, gentlemen, is a first-rate piece of ass. Tell the Sheriff I want to be introduced. She does not belong in a mudhole like this.
answer: Excuse me.

question: You again?
answer: That's my wife, General. She's a married woman.

question: Do you know what system of government we have here, son? A feudal system. Like the Middle Ages. With lords and vassals. That's you and me. Those lords, they had some ideas. If a vassal got married, it was the lord's right, his right, to sleep with the bride on the wedding night.
answer: Me and Abby have been married for three years.

question: You didn't have to --
answer: Didn't have to what, Sheriff? Your people seem seditious. You seem seditious.

question: Aw, Michael...
answer: What am I seeing here? I'm waiting.

question: Man came through here. With mail. Said he was a postman. Said the government had been restored back east.
answer: What government?

question: I managed to save these.
answer: Take that thing off, Johnny. You want to die, too?

question: I'm headed south. With the mail.
answer: Don't be a damn fool.

question: Make it quick. I've got an attack to coordinate.
answer: General, um, they've asked me to negotiate a peace treaty.

question: Do I know you?
answer: I don't think so, sir. I --

question: The restored United States. Do these people really believe that shit? Who are you really?
answer: I am a United States Postman. Authorized by order 417 of the restored Congress to --

question: I was at the Battle of Georgetown. I watched the White House burn to the ground. Don't try to sell me on any restored U.S...
answer: The new capital is based in Minneapolis. Inside the Hubert Humphrey Metrodome. You know, where the Vikings used to play?

question: You're funny. Now, what are the terms?
answer: They'll open the gate and give you double what they usually give. Just don't hurt anybody. This was all a misunderstanding.

question: We can't stop now. They'll be coming after us.
answer: Abby...

question: Don't move. You're right.
answer: Thank you. I don't think I ever had water soup before. Maybe next time we could try it with a little sand? Dirt? Wood? A twig garnish? You used to think I was funny.

question: They killed Michael.
answer: I'm sorry.

question: How sorry are you?
answer: What's that supposed to mean? What's with you?

question: You got the mark of eight on you.
answer: A mark doesn't mean I'm a --

question: You're a liar. I should've let you die.
answer: Then, why didn't you? You were with Bethlehem. Does that make you one of them? Don't make me use this. Wind's come up. Getting colder too. Must be another storm --

question: Anything else?
answer: I didn't mean for you to --

question: Your legs are going to rot off if you don't try to walk.
answer: I'm hurt.

question: You're lazy.
answer: Lazy?! I got a hole in my stomach. I'm weak. The two big meals around here are grass and snow. And we're running out of grass. Where are you going? You're not leaving me here, are you?

question: This is the last of it.
answer: Give me a break...

question: I'm going to check the pass.
answer: Why are you in such a hurry to get out of here? I can think of worse places. And worse company to -- You can't play tic-tac-toe with yourself.

question: Help!
answer: I can't help you.

question: I told you that's all there was.
answer: That's why you should have it.

question: I knew you could walk.
answer: You're weird, you know that? We walked on the moon once, Abby.

question: So? What good is that now?
answer: Obviously you've forgotten Tang and microwave ovens. Your face looks pretty. Not so bruised.

question: Look, there's something you'd better know. You're going to find out soon enough. I'm pregnant. It's Michael's baby. You're just the body father.
answer: How do you know it's mine and not Bethlehem's?

question: He tried with me almost every night. He couldn't do it. So he beat me. Said it was my fault.
answer: Abby. What is it? What's wrong? Is it the baby?

question: The pass is clear. It's time to go.
answer: What happened? You got our stuff out.

question: Of course.
answer: Of course? I don't understand.

question: I set the fire.
answer: Am I missing the point here?

question: You didn't think we'd stay here forever, did you? I'd appreciate if you'd walk with me long enough to find someplace safe for the baby. Then we can split up. You shaved.
answer: Yeah...

question: It looks nice.
answer: You're really weird, you know that? Have you ever heard of St. Rose, Abby?

question: I've heard people talk. I've heard lots of names. Bliss. Hesperia. New Eden. Sheriff Briscoe says it's a fantasy.
answer: He's wrong. St. Rose is out there. And I'm going to find it.

question: But you're The Postman.
answer: Look, I'm nobody, Abby. I'm just... This is what I hate. Strangers. Do you say 'hi' or do you blow their head off? Do they want to share what they got or take what you have? And if they want to take, how far are you willing to go to stop them? Damn it. All right. That's far enough. We don't want any trouble.

question: He's only the greatest man who ever lived. He crossed the wasteland, shook his fist at the enemy and spit in the eye of General Bethlehem himself. He's back east with President Starkey right now.
answer: Who told you all this?

question: Postmaster Ford Lincoln Mercury. He's in direct contact with the restored congress.
answer: Direct contact... I don't believe this.

question: Do you have mail, or don't you?
answer: You said Carrier Eighteen. That mean there's eighteen of you?

question: President Starkey? Minneapolis? Ford knows what to do?
answer: I thought you were dead.

question: So? I'm not making the connection. What's all this then?
answer: I lied. I told people you were in contact with me.

question: Why?
answer: Because I didn't want it to end.

question: I don't know how long I can stay, Ford. President Starkey will send word one day and I'll have to move on. Understand?
answer: Sure. But you'll stay till he sends word? Right?

question: Aw, don't do that. Hands down.
answer: You'll stay 'til President Starkey sends word, right? Right?

question: Yeah, till he sends word, right.
answer: Could you say a few words?

question: Two plus two equals four.
answer: We bring all the mail here first. We sort it, group it and then it goes out. So far we got thirty routes.

question: How old are you?
answer: Seventy-five, sir.

question: Can you ride?
answer: Nope. Can't walk too good, either.

question: Why are you here?
answer: I know stuff.

question: When did you get that?
answer: 1970. A girl with eyes as big as saucers did me in a little town called Saigon.

question: Abby --
answer: Yes?

question: Ford wants me to have his trailer. Said it's the best one.
answer: I'm on the other side of town.

question: What do you think, Lieutenant?
answer: Can't tell what it is if you stand too close. The colors all kinda run together, don't they?

question: Yes... Well, if it isn't our old friend the U.P.S. man.
answer: We captured him on the Oregon border.

question: Who the hell are you? I want the camp struck at dawn. We're moving north.
answer: Yes, sir.

question: Thank God it wasn't a carton of cigarettes.
answer: I'd have shot you myself. Things are getting better. Getting better all the time. I don't know who you are, but I do know I was wrong about you.

question: Got a letter for you, Sheriff.
answer: It's from my sister. I thought she was dead.

question: Who do you talk to?
answer: Not a soul in seven years of trying. But I will. Go ahead. Take a look. Want some?

question: No. No thanks. Hey, don't let the kids see that.
answer: I was an aerospace engineer. I helped design the Galileo space station. I dream it's orbiting Earth forever. With a dozen human skeletons all grinning at each other. Laughing at us down here.

question: Figures. They don't think to ask who they're replacing. Or why.
answer: Sir? It'd be an honor if I could shake your hand. Sir?

question: You look like... Do I know you?
answer: No, sir.

question: Where are you going?
answer: Route twenty-two. I'm already an hour late.

question: You're grounded. Get off the horse. You know the rule.
answer: What rule?

question: Twenty-two's too far south.
answer: But they're waiting on their mail down there.

question: Get off the goddamn horse. Tie him off to this one.
answer: You can't keep doing this.

question: Doing what?
answer: Riding all the routes. You're not saving anyone.

question: What are you going to do?
answer: I'm going to stop this.

question: You can't.
answer: Get out of my way, Ford. All of you.

question: They'll kill you.
answer: Goddamnit --

question: You can't help them!
answer: There's still time, Ford!

question: No, this is all my doing. I went against your orders. The Holnists we killed. You told me to bury them. But I didn't. I sent Bethlehem the bodies.
answer: Why?

question: Because Bethlehem has to know that we're not going to stop.
answer: God damn you, Ford. Those people down there are dying because of us. Because of what we did.

question: Bullshit. They're dying because of Bethlehem. They're dying because this is a shitty world. And if we're ever going to change it, then somebody might have to die. If I could make it be me down there I would. But I can't.
answer: My God, what have I done? We don't even know their names...

question: Ford thinks you're going to do something.
answer: I am. If I don't, those kids are going to keep on getting themselves killed.

question: Ford doesn't know what it means to be a kid. He doesn't have your memories. None of them do. All they've got is the lousy world we gave them. And this is the only decent thing in it.
answer: What? Being a postman? It's all bullshit, Abby. All of it. I took this uniform off a skeleton to stay warm. I made up the rest to stay fed. There is no restored United States.

question: I knew it was something like that.
answer: Weird thing is, being a Postman was almost the best thing that ever happened to me... Remember this? You left it behind that night.

question: I remember...
answer: I always liked to think you left it on purpose. But maybe you just forgot it. Is this everybody?

question: I always liked to think you left it on purpose. But maybe you just forgot it. Is this everybody?
answer: The rest are on the overdue list.

question: This is everybody. Got a letter from President Starkey. 'Greetings all carriers.' 'I've been in contact with The Postman. I've received all the reports. I'm proud of you all.' In dark days, in a weary world, you gave everything and asked for nothing. You beat back despair and replaced it with hope and for that your country can never repay you. But the price is too high. I won't see anymore of my bravest die. It is my duty to hereby disband the Postal Service of the restored United States. You are to burn your uniforms and The Postman is to return to Minneapolis at once. Thank you and that is all.
answer: The President never wrote that letter.

question: If he could've that's what he would have said.
answer: Who's the other letter to?

question: Bethlehem. I'm taking it to him in the morning.
answer: What does it say?

question: Mail's private. You know that.
answer: What does it say?

question: It says it's over. It says we quit.
answer: It says you quit. What about the oath?

question: Tell me something, Ford. How much mail can a dead postman deliver? It's over.
answer: Then I'll take it.

question: I can't trust you.
answer: If this is the end. If this is the last piece of mail that ever gets delivered. I'll take it.

question: Whoever takes this letter probably dies for it.
answer: I'm still a postman. You owe it to me... I owe it to me.

question: I'm going to St. Rose, Abby. And I'm taking you with me. I know you don't want to hear it, but that's my child inside you. I want to see it born somewhere safe. I have a right to that, Abby. Whether you like it or not. Thought I recognized you.
answer: General Bethlehem said... ... You should be on your knees when I do it.

question: I don't give a damn what that asshole said.
answer: The general is a great man.

question: Wait a minute... wait a minute!
answer: Sir?

question: Hold your fire! You don't know each other? This will never be over. It'll go on except I'll be fighting a goddamn ghost.
answer: Should we fire, sir?

question: This old thing? It isn't even loaded. Where are we?
answer: You're in Bridge City. Where we don't allow guns. Sentry said you were coming.

question: I know you. You're famous.
answer: I was once. Not anymore. Are you looking to cross?

question: We will be. Right now, we'd just appreciate some food. I got some kids behind me, too.
answer: How many?

question: Three. Hey, guys, come on in! I know you're out there!
answer: For you and your wife.

question: Thanks. She's not my wife. Let me ask you something, have you ever heard of a town with electric lights?
answer: St. Rose?

question: Yeah!
answer: Never been. But they say it's a ways down on the coast.

question: How far?
answer: Couple hundred miles at least. I couldn't say for sure.

question: You seem like a decent man. And these seem like decent people.
answer: We try to be.

question: And this seems like a safe place.
answer: You want to leave her?

question: All of them. I'll give you the horses and my gear. Abby's special. She's strong. Probably end up running the place.
answer: Why don't you take the night to think. Decide if that's what you really want. They're looking for The Postman. Man on the horse says there is. Says he thinks he's here. Says he's coming back with friends.

question: Are you The Postman?
answer: Yes.

question: I've heard of you, man. You're famous.
answer: Yeah, I guess I am. And all of a sudden, I'm not wearing the right clothes.

question: Fact that we don't allow 'em doesn't mean we don't have 'em. We're not stupid, after all.
answer: I'm sorry I've brought this on you.

question: ... We were outnumbered, sir.
answer: How many?

question: A least a hundred. With guns.
answer: With guns? Are you sure?

question: Yes, sir...
answer: Looks more like two hundred to me... Only thing worse than a coward is one who can't count. Lieutenant, do yourself a favor. Die well in this battle. In my army a deserter's life is a brief and unpleasant one. At last, someone with courage enough to bring the fight to me. Reckoning, gentlemen. This is the day I've dreamed of. They're an eager-looking bunch. Morale's a dangerous thing. Bring him up. I want this postman to see how the game is played.

question: Looks more like two hundred to me... Only thing worse than a coward is one who can't count. Lieutenant, do yourself a favor. Die well in this battle. In my army a deserter's life is a brief and unpleasant one. At last, someone with courage enough to bring the fight to me. Reckoning, gentlemen. This is the day I've dreamed of. They're an eager-looking bunch. Morale's a dangerous thing. Bring him up. I want this postman to see how the game is played.
answer: Stay here. No one moves until I give the orders.

question: God, I hope not. My little shipping clerk.
answer: We're both a couple of frauds. You know it; I know it.

question: Great men are made by other great men. Patton had Rommel. Grant had Lee. But I get you.
answer: You're no fucking general. You're a copying machine salesman. You're not even a good painter.

question: Are you trying to goad me into a fight?
answer: Wouldn't it be great if wars could be fought just by the assholes who started them? We could settle this thing right here. You and me.

question: Unfortunately, it doesn't work that way.
answer: It does in your army. I invoke law seven of the Laws of Eight! Any man may challenge for leadership of the clan!

question: What?
answer: I challenge you.

question: You're not a Holnist. You're not a member of the clan. You don't have the right.
answer: I have every right. I invoke law seven! I challenge for leadership of the clan!

question: Where do I know you from?
answer: 'Cry Havoc! And let slip the dogs of war.' Remember that?

question: Shakespeare. The one who didn't want to fight.
answer: I should've found a way to kill you then. But you seemed so strong.

question: Law seven it is. This war is settled here! I study people. I know your problem. Do you know why you can't fight? You have nothing to fight for. You don't care about anything. You don't value anything. You don't believe in anything. That's what makes me better.
answer: I believe in the United States Postal Service. Neither snow... Nor rain... Nor heat... Nor gloom of night... Will stay this courier from the swift completion of his appointed rounds... It doesn't have to be this way. We don't have to kill each other. We can live together. We can --

question: I believe in the United States Postal Service. Neither snow... Nor rain... Nor heat... Nor gloom of night... Will stay this courier from the swift completion of his appointed rounds... It doesn't have to be this way. We don't have to kill each other. We can live together. We can --
answer: Law three. Mercy is for the weak.

question: Ford, don't...
answer: Law eight. There is only one penalty and that penalty is death.
